natural problem:
The real function $f$ has the property that, whenever $a,$ $b,$ $n$ are positive integers such that $a + b = 2^n,$ the equation
\[f(a) + f(b) = n^2\]holds.  What is $f(2002)$?
natural solution: From the given property, \begin{align} f(2002) &= 11^2 - f(46), \\ f(46) &= 6^2 - f(18), \\ f(18) &= 5^2 - f(14), \\ f(14) &= 4^2 - f(2). \end{align}Also, $f(2) + f(2) = 4,$ so $f(2) = 2.$  Hence, \begin{align}

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b n. a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> n > 0 \<and> a + b = 2^n \<longrightarrow> f a + f b = n^2"
shows  "f 2002 = 96"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The real function $f$ has the property that, whenever $a,$ $b,$ $n$ are positive integers such that $a + b = 2^n,$ the equation
\[f(a) + f(b) = n^2\]holds.  What is $f(2002)$? The final Answer is 96
 ### Proof
 From the given property, \begin{align} f(2002) &= 11^2 - f(46), \\ f(46) &= 6^2 - f(18), \\ f(18) &= 5^2 - f(14), \\ f(14) &= 4^2 - f(2). \end{align}Also, $f(2) + f(2) = 4,$ so $f(2) = 2.$  Hence, \begin{align}
 f(14) &= 4^2 - 2 = 14, \\ f(18) &= 5^2 - 14 = 11, \\ f(46) &= 6^2 - 11 = 25, \\ f(2002) &= 11^2 - 25 = \boxed{96}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>a b n. a > 0 \<and> b > 0 \<and> n > 0 \<and> a + b = 2^n \<longrightarrow> f a + f b = n^2"
shows  "f 2002 = 96"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If $f$ is a function from integers to integers such that for all positive integers $a$, $b$, and $n$, if $a + b = 2^n$, then $f(a) + f(b) = n^2$. What is the value of $f(2002)$? The final answer is $96$.

 f(14) &= 4^2 - 2 = 14, \\ f(18) &= 5^2 - 14 = 11, \\ f(46) &= 6^2 - 11 = 25, \\ f(2002) &= 11^2 - 25 = \boxed{96}. \end{align}
 *)

 *)
